awd_abstract_narration: This award is made as part of the FY 2017 Mathematical Sciences Postdoctoral Research Fellowships Program. Each of the fellowships supports a research and training project at a host institution in the mathematical sciences, including applications to other disciplines, under the mentorship of a sponsoring scientist. The title of the project for this fellowship to Caitlin J. Leverson is "The Geometry and Algebra of Legendrian Submanifolds." The host institution for the fellowship is the Georgia Institute of Technology, and the sponsoring scientist is John Etnyre.
org_dir_long_name: Directorate for Mathematical and Physical Sciences

por.por_cntn:
The main scientific goal of this project was to advance the study of the relationships between the geometry of Legendrian knots and submanifolds and the algebra of the Legendrian contact homology differential graded algebra. The study of contact geometry goes back hundreds of years to the study of geometric optics, Hamiltonian dynamics, and thermodynamics. However, contact structures have only been studied extensively for the last few decades. In this time, surprising connections with low-dimensional topology and dynamics have emerged. The study of knots that respect a contact structure has yielded many results in contact geometry and topology of 3-manifolds. Legendrian contact homology has proven to be an important tool in the study of Legendrian submanifolds.

During the course of this project, Dan Rutherford and the PI established relationships between representation numbers of Legendrian contact homology differential graded algebra and specific polynomials involving Legendrian knots. They also introduced a new invariant of Legendrian knots, the n-colored m-graded ruling polynomial (analogous to the n-colored HOMFLY-PT polynomial), related the total n-dimensional m-graded representation number to it, and showed that in the 2-graded case it appears as a specialization of the n-colored HOMFLY-PT polynomial.

In this project, Sarah Blackwell, Noemie Legout, Maylis Limouzineau, Ziva Meyer, Yu Pan, Samantha Pezzimenti, Lara Simone Suarex, Lisa Traynor, and the PI wrote a paper which gives a survey of some known results about the existence and obstructions to the existence of exact Lagrangian coboridms which are derived from Heegaard Floed Homology and contact surgery. At this time it is unknown whether or not there exist nondecomposable exact Lagrangian cobordisms and this paper lays out methods that may provide a pathway to prove the existence of nondecomposable exact Lagrangian cobordisms.

During the course of the grant the PI co-organized 6 conferences varying from workshops for undergraduates to professional development workshops for graduate students and postdocs to research conferences, founded and organized a joint seminar between the University of Georgia and Georgia Institute of Technology, ran two REUs (research experiences for undergradates), and participated in numerous seminars, conferences, and workshops as well as doing outreach to elementary schoolers.

 

 


Last Modified: 10/07/2021
Modified by: Caitlin J Leverson
